relationships.evidence_text: Welcome to the Y on Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry.
recording with Rowdy Yates, the founder of High Plains Biochar.
Rowdy Yates is originally from Casper, Wyoming.
graduating from Oklahoma State University with a business degree.
owned a boat.construction business in Oklahoma.
He also lived in Texas.
He also lived in Texas and Nebraska.
the latter being the place where high planes biochar was founded.
The Rocket Char 301 technology you're going to hear a lot about that is one of the latest and greatest of high planes offerings.
In 2021, they built the first working pilot unit.
went through a Microsoft funded accelerator called G Beta.
they were chosen for a United States Department of Energy Technology Accelerator called Reach.
which is run by Colorado State University and Industry Ventures in Fort Collins, Colorado.
Earlier this year, 2022, Kevin Johnson joined the team.
is helping Rowdy now as they're accelerating and scaling up the technology.
working to create the world's first biochar cooperative.
participating members can verify and sell the carbon credits coming from the biochar production.
coming from the biochar production that group is responsible for.
that project is being created in collaboration with the Rocky Mountain Farmers Union.
biochar is charcoal created from cooking biomass at high temperatures in the absence of oxygen.
We typically use wood chips, but hemp, there's a lot of other feedstocks that you can use to make biochar with.
the properties of biochar that are making it such an important potential application in soil and even in other agricultural uses.
it's carbon that we can add to our soil, but it lasts for thousands of years.
which is much different than a lot of the other short-term soil amendments that are used.
a tree can pull carbon out of the atmosphere.
We turn that wood into a stable form of carbon that lasts for thousands of years in the soil.
that's how we're able to work with nature and actually remove carbon from the atmosphere.

relationships.evidence_text: the ancient Amazonians were creating terapreta, where they were adding charcoal and different things to the soils to grow more food
that's how they were able to improve the soil health to the point where they could actually grow large amounts of food on fairly small parts of land
what biochar is doing in the soil as a soil amendment for the plants and the water retention
using biochar and animal feed
adding biochar to asphalt projects
the biochar is helping to pass toxins
we've also seen benefits as far as increased milk output in dairies
we've done some research with the University of Nebraska doing a feed trial
we were actually able to reduce methane output from cattle by about 10 to 15 percent
the biochar itself makes for a asphalt that can be applied at lower temperatures
we're able to have these paving projects where actually sequestering carbon from the atmosphere while we're paving our streets
I have burnt some toast in the past
we tend to end up with just ash at the end
we're actually left with this really useful biochar
that's how we create the biochar. It's high temperature in the absence of oxygen, which is called pyrolysis.
the carbon structure of biochar is a very high carbon product.
But what that is in the soil is housing for microbes.
It gives them a structure to thrive in.
it's apartment complexes for our soil microbes and fungi and protozoa and all the other life going on in our soil.

So when a normal soil might dry out, a soil emitted with biochar might get two more days of available moisture to those roots.
you have a lot of flexibility in what you can use.
A saw mill might have sawdust and other waste that they're utilizing.
cities that don't have municipal urban waste available for a lot of their urban tree projects.
there's biomass and possible feedstock for biochar, just about everywhere you look.
Colorado State University helped us develop this control box.
this is doing is it's controlling the temperature.
this little PID controller here, we're running out about 1190 degrees right now.
We also have controls for things like ignition.
our bin vibrators.
our draft inducers.
we're able to control the speed of our fuel loggers.
our biochar auger.
we're using a quench pump here to actually stop that burning process.
turn the biochar and steam activate the biochar.
we're able to take a regular biochar and by steam quenching, we're able to open those pores up.
we're actually approaching the surface area of some activated carbons.
we're just using the heat that we generate from the process for the Steve activation.
this technology, one of the really unique features of this technology is it doesn't require a fan for moving air.
these can run on very little electricity.
our goal is to create the first carbon negative technology that runs on its own energy.
with a thermoelectric generator utilizing the heat from the exhaust stack.
This machine right now is only consuming about 1.2 amps of electricity while operating.
this technology requires very very little electricity to operate.
the structure we're in currently with the unit is your machine shop.
you and I met I think something like five, six years ago.
you've been down to a couple of our Y on Earth events over the years.
the way you've shown up and shared and educated folks about the opportunities we have with biochar.
you are really one of these inventor entrepreneur types.
who has figured out a way to make this technology very simple.
requiring very little in the way of operational maintenance.
couple of our Y on Earth events over the years.
the opportunities we have with biochar.
what you're able to do in your machine shop, Routing, it's extraordinary.
you are really one of these inventor entrepreneur types.
make this technology very simple.
very foolproof and requiring very little in the way of operational maintenance.
this can get deployed in communities, farms, places, even all around the world.
this is going to bring a lot of different benefits into people's lives.
what are some of the challenges that you've seen with other technologies that you've been able to kind of solve out of this technology?
there's a need for more biochar technologies right now.
A lot of the older technologies that are available aren't super energy efficient.
they require a lot of electricity to operate.
A lot of them don't utilize that heat that they're generating.
a lot of them use fossil fuels for startup process.
there's a lot of improvement to be made in some of those technologies.
we just tried to keep things simple.
the sky's the limit here because this technology is small scale.
this technology is small scale and can be used on a farm in India.
or a farm in Indiana.
this machine is removing about six pounds of carbon dioxide per hour from the atmosphere.
The average person admits about four tons of carbon dioxide per year.
this machine is enough to actually offset an entire person's carbon footprint for the year.
you're getting all those additional ancillary benefits, amending soil and so on.
that he can be utilized to heat a greenhouse.
heat a shop building.
heat a house.
you're also getting the biochar to enhance your soil.
there's biochar carbon credits that are associated with producing biochar.
that are worth about a hundred dollars a ton.
there's really three different kind of income streams from utilizing a waste product and turning it into biochar.
this whole carbon credit piece has really gotten exciting the last couple of years.
there's been this kind of background discussion of when the carbon markets come alive.
we're thinking maybe five dollars, maybe $10 a ton.
we've got a very active carbon market.
we're seeing some very exciting pricing signals coming from the global carbon market.
what's your sense about the role biochar is going to be playing over the next several years.
as a global community here is responding to the very serious.
we've got a very active carbon market.
how have you seen the picture with the carbon trading evolved these last several years?

the ease of measuring and documenting the removal of the carbon just by simply bagging and weighing the biochar.
I think it'll be pretty stable in that range.

it feels like biochar is slowly gaining momentum and climbing gets away towards the top of kind of that list of the best ways to remove carbon from the atmosphere.
a lot of our colleagues are working on other aspects of regenerative agricultural solutions.
when you add a ton of biochar to the soil, you've got that ton of carbon sequestered value, but you're also stimulating a lot of additional soil building activity.

there were some studies out of Australia now that are in the past their five years since they began and we're starting to see that you're right, there was an initial boost from adding the biochar to the soil.
